answer:
1) Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis

• Frame 1 and Frame 2: The ego is queued in traffic, approaching a multi‐lane city intersection. Overhead signals include arrows and “ONLY” signage for each lane. Although multiple vehicles are ahead, it appears the ego is to the right of the through‐traffic lane.  
• Frame 3: The overhead signals become clearer, showing separate lanes designated “ONLY” for left turns, straight‐through travel, and right turns. The ego’s lane seems aligned with the right‐turn‐only signage.  
• Frame 4: The pavement marking directly in front of the camera shows a large right‐arrow with “ONLY,” confirming that this lane must turn right.  
• Frame 5: The same right‐turn‐only marking is fully visible. No lane markings or signs suggest the ego may legally go straight or left; the only permissible maneuver is turning right.

2) Contextual Reasoning  
Because the pavement arrow and overhead sign both dictate a right turn only, and there is no indication that traffic or signage would force an immediate stop (beyond a routine red‐light stop), the lane choice and signage make turning right the imminent action.  

3) Match to Answer Choices  
A (Turn left) and B (Go straight) conflict with the “Right‐turn‐only” lane markings. D (Stop) might occur briefly if the signal is red, but the question asks for the ego’s “immediate most likely action” in terms of direction/maneuver; that would be turning right once permitted.  

4) Provide the Best Answer  
Turning right is the only lane‐compliant maneuver.  

<answer>C</answer>
